steps.title: Check the dog's size.
steps.content: Check the dog's size. Havanese are rather small dogs. They are only 8.5–11.5 inches (21.6–29.2 cm) tall and weigh 7–13 pounds (3.2–5.9 kg). steps.title: Look at the eyes.
steps.content: Look at the eyes. The Havanese have large, dark brown eyes which are almond-shaped. The eyes have solid black rims. Chocolate-coloured dogs may have slightly lighter eyes and brown eye rims instead of black. [4] X Trustworthy Source American Kennel Club Expert knowledge, resources and advice for all things dog-related. Go to source

steps.title: Inspect the ears.
steps.content: Inspect the ears. Havanese have broadly-based ears which are set high on the head. When the dog is alert, the ears will lift at the base but always remain folded. [5] X Trustworthy Source American Kennel Club Expert knowledge, resources and advice for all things dog-related. Go to source

steps.title: Notice the muzzle.
steps.content: Notice the muzzle. A Havanese's muzzle is slightly less in length than the skull, and it is full and rectangular with a broad nose. The dog's nose and lips are a solid black except for in chocolate coloured dogs, in which they have a solid brown pigment. [6] X Trustworthy Source American Kennel Club Expert knowledge, resources and advice for all things dog-related. Go to source

steps.title: Examine the tail.
steps.content: Examine the tail. Havanese have tails which are set high and arch forward up, over the back. The tail is plumed with long silky hair. The tail plume can either fall forward or to either side of the body, and whilst the dog is standing the tail might be dropped. [7] X Trustworthy Source American Kennel Club Expert knowledge, resources and advice for all things dog-related. Go to source

steps.title: View the overall structure.
steps.content: View the overall structure. The Havanese has a slightly arched neck, and the body is slightly longer than the height at the withers. The top of the shoulder blades lie in at the withers, allowing the neck to blend smoothly into the back. They have muscular hind legs with a moderate amount of angulation. [8] X Trustworthy Source American Kennel Club Expert knowledge, resources and advice for all things dog-related. Go to source

steps.title: Check the coat's texture and appearance.
steps.content: Check the coat's texture and appearance. A Havanese has a coat which is silky and light in texture on both the outer and undercoat, although the outercoat carries more weight. The coat is long, abundant and wavy, standing off the body slightly but flowing with movement. steps.title: Take notice of the coat colour.
steps.content: Take notice of the coat colour. A Havanese can be any colour, but there are some colours that are seen more frequently. These standard colours include: black, chocolate, cream, fawn, gold, red, silver, and white. steps.title: Look at the 'cut'.
steps.content: Look at the 'cut'. Some people choose to give their Havanese specific haircuts rather than just leaving it as the standard cut. Some of these cuts may include the Teddy Bear cut, the Kennel cut, the Natural cut, Cording, and the Puppy cut. [13] X Research source The Teddy Bear cut appears as the same length all over (usually around 3 inches) apart from the head, where the hair is fluffy and cut in a rounded shape. [14] X Research source The Kennel cut is seen as clipping the hair much shorter all over. [15] X Research source The Natural cut is a long, wavy cut which has been left to grow all over. [16] X Research source Cording seems similar to human dreadlocks, and their hair naturally develops into cords if left long enough. [17] X Research source The Puppy cut is seen as cut to the same short length all over (usually 1–2 inches). [18] X Research source

steps.title: Watch for affection.
steps.content: Watch for affection. Havanese are affectionate dogs and love more than anything to be around their people. steps.title: Notice playfulness.
steps.content: Notice playfulness. A Havanese is a playful and funny little dog. They'll love to play games like hide and seek with items around the house. The Havanese is often the family clown; they love making you laugh and being the centre of attention. [20] X Research source

steps.title: See how companionable the dog is.
steps.content: See how companionable the dog is. The Havanese is a gentle, peaceful dog, but is also not one that can be left alone for a long time. [21] X Research source

steps.title: Look for responsiveness.
steps.content: Look for responsiveness. Havanese are very responsive dogs who will listen to their owner's commands because they want to please them. They'll learn tricks quickly because of this intelligence and desire to please their owners. Unlike some other breeds, their intelligence doesn't give them a sense of superiority, and they won't try to dominate you during training. [22] X Research source

steps.title: Pay attention to how sociable the dog is.
steps.content: Pay attention to how sociable the dog is. The Havanese loves their owners, but will also become friends with other people, dogs, and pets. They are great with children, and children tend to love them because of how playful they are. [23] X Research source

steps.title: Notice barking.
steps.content: Notice barking. The Havanese tends to bark at every little sound, which can become quite annoying. If you acknowledge the barking, to make sure that everything's alright, the dog will generally quiet down. They will alert you when someone is coming and greet them happily when they arrive.
